Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 07:13PM Hood1980 wrote: Hi Genia,  My prayers go out for you!  Your case is very similar to mine and we can talk if you like.  just PM me.  I had ILC a 4.5 cm tumor that the dr said had been hiding in thick tissue for years.   Lobular cancers are tricky I am sure you have been told or read about with long single cell tentacles which make them larger by nature than ductal cancers.  But all my scans & nodes were clear!  I had a simple mastectomy & SNB on 6/13/08 and started 4 rounds of chemo last week.  You can beat this!  I am here for you!

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2012 10:53AM - edited Feb 14, 2012 10:57AM by Hood1980 By all means ask for your reports and start a file for them. Keep your own historical records for your own peace of mind.  It's good to have last year's record to compare to your most recent tests. I don't know your doctor, but from a woman that has had many a doctor check her breasts, they all talk while they are massaging/checking your breasts.  It's probably part of their training to help ease the patient's anxiety.  I too have a lumpy breast and it's the one I still have.  That sneaky cancer was hiding out in the other more desnse less lumpy one, go figure.  I agree with momof 3boys.  Be thankful your doctor is being proactive and requesting an mri now.  My cancer went undetected through years of mammograms, ultrasounds & biopsies.  When I was finally referred for an mri, I had a 4.5 cm tumor.  The lump I found myself & was never detected by mammo or US!  Breast mri's were relatively new when I had mine & I wish every woman diagnosed has having dense of fibrocystic breasts would be referred for an mri. We are all here for you.  I know it's scary, but it is probably nothing.  But with dense breasts, please be vigilant with your breast exams & trust your gut if you think something needs to be checked out.  Take care!
Posts.Title: lumpy breasts girlguru Hood1980

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 10:17AM Hood1980 wrote: I'm on the Clodronate too.  I started Nov 17th and take mine first thing in the morning, since you have to take it on an empty stomach, remain upright, and not eat for at least 30 mins after taking it.  I also have to take the extra Vit D & Calcium supplements.  I did have some stomach/acid reflux issues, even before starting the this new med, and the onc prescribed Protonix (a proton pump inhibitor) and I haven't had any problems so far.
